resource.chars: Therefore may you grant that it be a short while
Before I have recourse to your assistance.
In this way I will be able, my lady, to live in hope.
Ah, nobility seated in a noble body,
Sweetness of face, generosity of the heart,
May you have pity on your lover,
Who has placed his intentions in you.
In the world, he does not value anything else,
Nor does he ask for anything else.
God, it would be too cruel
Sweet lady, since you know
My pain, and that I have attached my heart
To serving you completely,
That you suffer that in bad fortune
I die, without deserving it.
Deserving it? Alas! That in my life
I have committed a fault towards you
In deeds or in words, this cannot be!
Alas! Where would such furor come from?
Truly, if I had committed such a fault,
I must have been born under a bad star!
And how, sweet, gracious one,
Would you be so against me,
If you do not know me to have erred,
That you would desire my death?
Alas! Certainly, you do not have the reputation
Or the appearance of being so cruel!
Therefore, noble body and bright face,
May you deign that your generous heart,
Which loves you without deception,
Grant me grace through sweetness and pity.
God! Will I see you in such a place
As to deign to receive me willingly?
Alas! And I have the right, if I dare to say it,
To be worthy of such a lofty thing,
Through my person and my merits,
If you, lily and rose of beauty,
Through the sweetness that resides in you,
Do not grant me grace, certainly.
Oh, lady who is loved with an ardent heart,
Begged for by me night and day,
Now may your grace be opened to me
For I die of ardor of enflamed love,
And no word has been spoken of this
Except for what I have revealed to you above.
Therefore, lady, make sure
That no one knows my torments; this concerns
Only you, and one cannot counsel me
Since I am now exclusively under your power.
By God, may your assistance come quickly!
It is time to direct your attention towards this!
Dear lady, I have great fear
That my relief be compromised
By two things; I fear each of them!
That to your sweet company
Someone other than me
Aspires, with your agreement. This is one.
The other is this: I fear that when I come
Near you in order to beg you, it seems
That I do not serve you except with hypocritical words,
Since I do not tremble or waver,
And when company is assembled,
That I sing and play and enjoy myself.
Alas! As for the first fear,
I pray that death strike me down
Before things become as I have imagined!
I would much rather be in a coffin
Than be put aside for another
By she whom I love so much; I would go crazy!
As to the other, dear lord God,
When I come close to you, my lady, as much
As I am able, I am given courage and force.
He could well be disposed in such a way
For this reason, I exert myself in my behavior.
Moreover, if I sing or joke
Or play games in company,
It might be to entertain,
But it is not at all because of this.
One plays well when the heart is troubled
In order to attenuate many evil rumors.
Alas! Since I am suffering, where would I get the idea
To play or to distract myself now,
Or to be happy at the right moment,
If one understands my situation well?
If I am happy in any way,
It is right that I am happy with no reason!
Without a reason? Truly, do not doubt it!
Alas! For I am thrown into the fire of love,
Which burns my heart and breaks my body;
I am stationed to suffer torments.
I cannot make my lady hear me
Through any request that I make.
Sweet lady, may it not displease you
If what I think, which hurts me,
I have told you through a guessing game,
For I suffer so much both day and night
From that which burns my hurt,
Whatever comes out of my mouth.
Nevertheless, my lady, in all that I have said
I have never criticized you,
In the hope that everything I fear is nothing.
But a sick man or one who is mistreated
Criticizes himself through too many thoughts,
Sometimes to his disadvantage, sometimes to his advantage.
Oh, lady in love through sweetness,
I die and languish in life.
My heart is blackened with burning
If you, very sweet, delicious one,
Do not relieve me without waiting
And give me hope of mercy.
When a man remains languishing
And does not have hope—for a day or an hour—
That one will rescue him
And everyday misfortune surrounds him,
I say truly, may God help me,
That one can compare this state to death.
Lady, you who give me these pains,
You make them flourish within me
By diminishing my hope for mercy,
That I have resigned myself to lamenting;
But I have a reason to abandon myself
To complaining more than any other.
Alas! But what does it mean to complain
If in you, lady, to whom I recount
My woes, I cannot find any help—
If, truly, you do not take any account of me?
No misfortune is greater than mine.
I can prove that I am devastated!
And nevertheless, my lady of high nobility,
Because I cannot explain well
My distress to you when I am present,
So much does the anguish of love constrain me,
For this reason, I address myself to you through this dit,
Which I give as a gift to you.
May you let yourself, noble, courteous and gracious one,
Be so acquainted with sweetness
That you deign to consider me with pity,
For in my heart, through the amorous arrow
Of your sweet love is attached to me
The burning from which I cannot protect myself.
May you do this, if it is your wish,
My lady, according to what is appropriate,
And envisage following its generosity,
For pain holds me because of love for you,
And my heart suffers it willingly,
If I must die or live through you,
I will die in this way without meriting it,
Even if my death is not a great loss.
It would seem to be very cruel
To find pity scarce
In a lady who is so noble and intelligent
And in whom there is so much sense and beauty.
Certainly, no one who looked well
At your noble body and your sweet face
Would think of this;
Rather, it would always be affirmed
